div.p: RELIGION.
VVithout the knowledge whereof none may preſume to come to the Lords Table here or expect to communicate with him in glory hereafter.

Collected out of a more copious Catechiſme, and publiſhed eſpecially for the benefit of ſuch poore Soules, as want:
Either money to buy,
Or time to learne,
Or memories to retaine
a larger Treatiſe.

q.p: When for the time ye ought to be Teachers, yee haue need that one teach you againe, which be the firſt Principles of the Oracles of God, and are become ſuch as haue need of milk, and not of ſtrong meate.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by WILLIAM IONES, and are to be ſolde by Francis Coules dwelling in the Old Bayly, neere to Newgate, 1630.

q.p: Theſe words which I command thee this day ſhall be in thine heart: and thou ſhalt teach them diligently unto thy children, and ſhalt talke of them when thou ſitteſt in thine houſe, and when thou walkeſt by the way, and when thou lyeſt downe, and when thou riſeſt vp.
Sanctifie the Lord God in your hearts, and be ready alwayes to giue an anſwer to every man that asketh you a reaſon of of the hope that is in you, with meekeneſſe and feare.

div.head: THE MAINE GROVNDS OF RELIGION.

p.label: Queſtion.
p.hi: OF what Religion are you?

div.p: Anſwer. Of the Chriſtian Religion.Acts 11, 24

p.hi: Q. What Religion is that?

div.p: A. Acts 4, 12. That which teacheth men to looke for true and euerlaſting happineſſe by Chriſt alone.

p.hi: Q. Where is this Religion taught?

div.p: A. In the holy Scriptures of the Old and New Teſtament.

p.hi: Q. What may wee learne out of the Scriptures?

div.p: A. Two things:Iohn 17, 3 Eccle: 7, 29 the knowledge of God, and of our ſelues.

p.hi: Q. What are wee taught concerning God?

div.p: A. That there are thrée Perſons,1 Iohn 5, 7 Prov. 16, 4 Mat: 10, 29 yes but one God, who is the Ordainer, the Maker, and Gouernour of all things.

p.hi: Q. What are we taught concer •••• our ſelues?

div.p: Gen. 1 26.. and 3, 1, 2. Rom. 5.12 A. That Man and Woman bein • made in the Image of God, fell from the bleſſed eſtate, and became moſt curſed Creatures.

p.hi: Q. What is then the eſtate of every naturall man?

div.p: Eph. 2.3. Rom. 7.24 A. Very miſerable, and in no wiſe to be reſted in.

p.hi: Q. What maketh his eſtate ſo bad?

div.p: Eſa. 59.2. Rom. 6.23 A. Two things: Sinne and the puniſhment thereof.

p.hi: Q. What call you Sinne?

div.p: 1 Ioh. 3.4. A. Euery breach of Gods Law.

p.hi: Q. How doth man breake the Law of God?

div.p: Eſay 1 15.16, 17. and 64.6. A. By doing things forbidden, leauing things commanded, or failing in the manner.

p.hi: Q. What is the puniſhment of ſinne?

div.p: Deut. 28.15. Luk 16 22 23 A. All miſeries in this life, death in the end, and hell euer after.

p.hi: Q. Is ſinne ſuch a grieuous thing?

div.p: A. Yea, it is the moſt hainous and loathſome thing in the world.

p.hi: Q. How appeareth that?

div.p: Heb. 10.31 and 12.29 A. Both by the puniſhment, and by the perſon againſt whom it is committed.

p.hi: Q. Who is that?

div.p: A. Almighty God, whoſe Holineſſe,1 Cor. 10.2 • . Pſa 36, 5, 6 Power, Iuſtice and Goodneſſe is infinite and vnſpeakable.

p.hi: Q. What ſhall a man doe in that wofull eſtate?

div.p: A. Bewaile his miſery,Act. 2.37. and haſten to get out of it.

p.hi: Q. Is he able of himſelfe to doe this?

div.p: A. No: and beſides he hath thrée enemies, the fleſh, the Deuill, and the world,2 Cor, 3:5 Eph. 6.12. that will labour to holde him in it.

p.hi: Q. Where ſhall a man finde help?

div.p: A. Onely in Ieſus Chriſt,Ioh. 146. the onely begotten Sonne of God.

p.hi: Q. What hath he done to deliuer man out of miſery?

div.p: A. He became man and in our nature fully ſatiſfied the Law & Iuſtice of God.Gal. 4.4, 5

p.hi: Q How hath he done this?

div.p: A By bearing for vs the puniſhment which the Law threatneth;Gal. 3.13. Mat. 3.15. and fulfilling the righteouſneſſe which the Law requireth.

p.hi: Q How did Chriſt beare the puniſhment due to ſinne by the Law?

div.p: A By enduring manifold miſeries all his life time, and in the end the wrath of God, and the curſed death of the Croſſe.Luk. 9.58. Phil. 2.8.

p.hi: Q. How did he worke the righteouſneſſe requyred by the Law?

div.p: A. By being obedient to the will of God,1 Pet. 2, 22 Iohn 4, 34 in thought, word, and doed, all his life long.

p.hi: Q. What benefit haue we by Chriſt his death and ſufferings?

div.p: Heb. 2, 14, 15. A. Deliuerance from ſinne, and the puniſhment thereof.

p.hi: Q. And why by his righteouſneſſe and obedience?

div.p: Rom. 5, 18 19, 11. A. The fauour of God, and everlaſting happineſſe.

p.hi: Q. How may we obtaine theſe benefits by Chriſt?

div.p: Iohn 1, 12. A. Onely by true faith in him.

p.hi: Q. What is a true Faith in Chriſt?

div.p: Rom. 1, 16 Iohn 6, 69 2 Tim 2, 12 A. It is a beliefe of the Goſpell, wherby a man doth truely reſt, and caſt himſelfe vpon Chriſt alone, for remiſſion of ſinnes, and eternall ſalvation.

p.hi: Q. Is it in our power to beleeue?

div.p: Eph. 2, 8 Gal: 5, 22 Rom. 10, 17. A. No: it is the gift of God, by the working of the Spirit, throgh the preaching of the Goſpell.

p.hi: Q. Shall all beleevers haue benefit by Chriſts death?

div.p: A. All that truely beléeue ſhall: but there is a dead faith that profiteth no thing.

p.hi: Q. How is the true faith perceived?

div.p: A. By the fruits thereof,1 Iohn 3, 3 and namely by repentance.

p.hi: Q. Why ſo?

div.p: A. Becauſe whereſoeuer Gods Spirit worketh true Faith,Acts 15, 5 there he worketh repentance alſo.

p.hi: Q. What is repentance?

div.p: A. Such a change of the heart,Rom: 12, 2 as bringeth forth a reformed life.

p.hi: Q. Whence commeth this change?

div.p: A. Eſpecially from the ſight and feeling of Gods mercy towards vs in Chriſt.1 Ioh: 4, 19

p.hi: Q. From what is the heart changed?

div.p: A. From the loue of the world to the loue of God:1 Ioh: 2, 15 Tit: 2, 12 from careleſnes to conſcience, and deſire to pleaſe God.

p.hi: Q. What is the change called?

div.p: A. It is called in Scripture a new creature.2 Cor: 5, 17

p.hi: Q. How doth it appeare?

div.p: A. When in word and déed wée endeauoure to abſtaine from euill,Eſ: 1, 16, 17 Eph. 4, 21 23, 24. and to exerciſe our ſelues in that which is gold.

p.hi: Q. Is this change of heart and minde perfect in any?

div.p: A. No: we beléeue not perfectly,Mark: 2, 24 1 Cor: 13, 9 Heb: 6, 1. and therefore wée cannot loue perfectly, but wée muſt ſtriue to perfection.

p.hi: Q How muſt we ſtriue?

div.p: A By a diligent vſe of the mea ••• which God hath appointed for our increaſe in faith and repentance.

p.hi: Q. What are the publike meanes?

div.p: A. They are chiefly thrée: hearing the word,Luc: 22, 19 Ro: 10, 13, 14, receiuing the Sacrament, and ioyning in Prayer.

p.hi: Q What are the Sacraments?

div.p: Ro: 4, 11: 1 Cor: 10: 16; A Certaine outward ſignes and ſeale appointed of God, to aſſure vs yt Chriſt and all his benefits are giuen to vs.

p.hi: Q How many Sacraments are there?

div.p: 1 Cor: 10, 32, 34, A Two, Baptiſme, and the Lords Supper.

p.hi: Q What doth Baptiſme aſſure vs of?

div.p: A That being ingrafted into Chriſt; wée are waſhed from our ſinnes in his blood,Gal: 3, 27: Tit: 3, 5: and borne anew in God.

p.hi: Q What doth the Lords Supper aſſure vs of?

div.p: 1 Cor: 11 24 Ioh: 6, 54, A It doeth further warrant vs that Chriſt is giuen to vs to be our ſpirituall nouriſhment to euerlaſting life.

p.hi: Q Who maketh the right vſe of the Sacraments?

div.p: Mat, 26: 28 Gal. 6, 15, A He that is thereby daily confirmed in faith and newnes of life.

p.hi: Q Who obtaine this benefit by the Lords Supper?

div.p: A Such as come with knowledge,1 Cor. 11, 28. faith, repentance and loue.

p.hi: Q. What is Prayer?

div.p: A. Acrauing of thoſe things at Gods hands which wée want,Pſa. 50.15 Phil: 4.6. and thanking him for thoſe we haue.

p.hi: Q. When doe men pray a right?

div.p: A When they pray onely to God,Ioh: 16.23 Iam, 4, 3, in the name of Chriſt: asking things lawfull, to his glory, with faith, féeling and loue.

p.hi: Q. What be the private meanes?

div.p: A. Reading and praying both alone,Deut, 17, 19 Mat. 7, 7 Gen 18, 19 and 24, 63 1 The, 5, 11 Pſa, 119, 9 and with others inſtructing our families, thinking vpon good matters, admoniſhing and comforting one another, & watching ouer our owne wayes according to the word.

p.hi: Q What will the right vſe of all theſe meanes work in Gods children?

div.p: A A moſt happy and comfortable change, from that which they were before, euen in this life.Acts 26, 18 1 Co, 6, 11

p.hi: Q What becommeth of them after this life?

div.p: A The ſoule goeth immediately into the Paradiſe of God, and the body ſhall be raiſed vp at the laſt day,Luk, 19, 22 1 Cor, 16.52. Mat 25, 46 and ioyned with the ſame in glory for euer.

p.hi:
Q. What is the portion of all ••••
rant or prophane perſons, who contemne theſe meanes of grace?

div.p: Deu: 28, 20 65, 66, 67 2 Theſ: 1, 9 Luke 13, 8 Mat: 25, 41 & 13, 49, 50. A. They are in a moſt curſed condition while they liue héere, and hereafter they ſhall be baniſhed from the joyes of heauen, and ſhall for euermore bee tormented with the Deuill in Hell, when is wéeping and wailing, and gnaſhing of téeth.

div.head: Certaine Rules for the direction of a Chriſtian life, expreſſed in Meeter, for helpe to the memory.

lg.head: A
lg.l:
Prov: 4, 2 Luk: 21, 3 Ioſu: 7, 21 Gen: 39, •
ACquaint thy ſelfe most narrowly,
Thy mind, thy heart, and life to watch:
Lest idle thoughts and noyſome dreames,
Doe wicked lusts and dealings hatch.

lg.head: B
lg.l: Eph: 5, 1 • Pſal: 90, 1 • Mat: 6, 33 Luk: 10, 41Be wiſe and carefull to redeeme,
Thy precious time to holy deedes:
Let not theſe earthly matters baſe,
Conſume more houres than thou muſt needs

lg.head: C
lg.l: Pſal: 52, 1 • Dan: 6, 1 • Pſal: 6.6. & 4, 4, 8Call to thy minde when night is come,
Thy ſinnes that day to crave releaſe:
Thinke on Gods favours him to prayſe,
That ſo thou maist lie downe in peace.

lg.head: D
lg.l:
Gen: 18, 1 • Psa: 27, • & 90, 14 • 15, 16, 1 •
Doth morne approach and ſleepe depart,
First lift thy heart to God on high:
Commit thy ſelfe and wayes to him,
And vowe to ſerve him faithfully.

lg.head: E
lg.l: Enter vpon no kinde of worke,
But craue Gods Spirit thee to protect:
Goe to no place or company,
But pray from ill mee to direct.

lg.head: F
lg.l: 1 Tim, 4, 5 1 Cor, 10 1: Mat, 14 • 6 and 26 • 6Forget not when thou meanſt to vſe,
Gods creatures, or his mercy ſweete:
For ſoules delight, or bodies health,
To craue his leaue and bleſſing meete.

lg.head: G
lg.l: Deu, 8, 10 and 32, 15 Pſa, 68, 19 Mat: 16, 30Giue vnto God due thanks and praiſe,
When comfortable vſe thou haſt:
Or any of his bleſſings good,
Or elſe he counts them ſpent in waſt.

lg.head: H
lg.l: Ioh, 4, 24 • Sam, 1, • 3 Pſ, 5, 2 and 30, 11Hold this for ſure, that in true prayer,
The hearts deſire is chiefeſt thing:
Yet voice will help the ſame to warme,
And baniſh dulneſſe and wandring.

lg.head: I
lg.l: Gen, 24, • 3, Dan, 6 • 0, Psa, 55, • 7, and 19, 164(If poſſibly thou canſt it finde)
Set out ſome time of euery day:
To muſe, to pray, and reade good bookes,
That grace and conſcience increaſe may.

lg.head: K
lg.l: Prov, 16, 4 Mat, 10, 29 Eccleſ, 9, 2 Mat, 25, 33Keep heart and minde much bent to thinke
How God hath made and ruleth all:
How here he deales with good and bad,
How differ in the end they ſhall.

lg.head: L
lg.l: Like beſt to ponder Christ his workes,Rom, 5, 2 1 Cor, 2, Gal, 6, 14, Phil, 3, 8,
How he thee ſau'd from ſinne and ſhame:
And made thee heire of Paradiſe,
Delight therein and praiſe his name.

lg.head: M
lg.l: Marke well the liues of good and bad,Eſa, 37, 37 Mat. 25, 26 Luk, 16, 23 Iam, 5, 10
Conſider eke the ends of both:
To moue thee for to imitate,
The vertuous man, and ſinners loath.

lg.head: N
lg.l: Nurture thy ſoule with thoughts of death,Pſa, 39.4 Heb, 9, 27, Luke, 12, 20 Col, 3, 1
That needs thou muſt from hence remoue:
(Leauing thy wealth and deareſt things)
To fixe thy minde on heauen aboue.

lg.head: O
lg.l: Obſerue how thy corruption dyes,Gal, 6, 14 Iob 20, 12 Mat, 5, 29 and 16, 2
Let not thy deareſt friend deceiue thee:
Why ſhouldſt thou count that ſweet and good,
Which may of glory quite bereaue thee.

lg.head: P
lg.l: Practiſe Gods worſhip with delight,Deu, 28, 47 Pſa, 16, 3 and 116, 10 2 Co, 7, 11
Ioy in the godlies company:
VVith God thy couenant oft renew,
Mourne for thy ſinne, and it defie.

lg.head: Q
lg.l: Quench not thine owne and others Spirit,1 The, 5, 19 Eph, 4, 19 Eze, 13, 22 Mat, 5, 6
All idle or vnſauory speech:
By thy behaviour euery where,
Let good, no ill to others teach.

lg.head: R
lg.l: Exod: 20, 7 Deu: 28, 58 Pſal: 15, 3 Mat: 5, 44Rehearſe no name, no worke, nor word
Of God, without high reverence:
Speake of no man but lovingly,
Although it be in thy defence.

lg.head: S
lg.l: Act: 24, 16 Eph: 5, 22, 25. & 6, 1, 4, 5, 6.Seeke to approove thy ſelfe to God,
Thy conſcience, and Gods children deare
By dealing in thy calling, and
With ſuch to whom thou art most neare.

lg.head: T
lg.l: Eph: 6, 12 Ier: 17, 9 2 Tim: 3, 5 Rev: 3, 16Take heede lest Satans craft (by meanes
Of natures bent t'hypocriſie,
And to profaneſſe) make thee uſe
Religious duties formally.

lg.head: V
lg.l: Mat: 15, 8, & 10, 28, & 6, 3, 4, 5, 6.Vſe not the ſame for faſhions ſake,
Or for thy credit, but with care
Thy God to pleaſe, that in the end
Both ſoule and body well may fare.

q.p: Conſider what I ſay, and the Lord give thee underſtanding in all things.

div.head: Grace before meate.
div.p: Moſt gracious God and louing Father, we humbly beſeech thée to forgiue vs all our ſinnes. Be preſent with vs, and bleſſe vs, and thy good creatures prouided for vs. Giue vs grace to receiue them thankefully as from thy hand, and to vſe them ſoberly as in thy ſight, is thy glory and our owne comfort, through Ieſus Chriſt our Lord. Amen.

div.head: Grace after meate.
div.p: We humbly thanke thée, O Lord heauenly Father, for refreſhing our fraile bodies with thy good creatures, beſeeching thee likewiſe to feed our ſoules with thy liuely word, that we may glorifie thée, both with our ſoules and with our bodies through Ieſus Chriſt our Lord.
Bleſſe good Lord thy holy Church, our gracious King, his Royall Familie and Realme, and ſend vs eternall life, through Ieſus Chriſt our Lord. Amen.
